page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 7: Line 7:
== February ==
== February ==
â
=== 12 February ===
+
=== 12-15 February ===
â
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
 
[[File:Clean-up in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|left|Volunteers use shovels to dispose rubble, debris, and trash.]]
[[File:Clean-up in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|left|Volunteers use shovels to dispose rubble, debris, and trash.]]
A group of activists issued what they called the "People's CommuniquÃ© No 1", imitating the titles of communiquÃ©s from the Army. It demanded the dissolution of the cabinet Mubarak had appointed on 29 January; the suspension of the parliament elected in late 2010 in a poll widely suspected of rigging; the creation of a transitional five-member presidential council made up of four civilians and one military person; the formation of a transitional government to prepare for an election to take place within nine months, and of a body to draft a new democratic constitution; freedom for the media and syndicates, which represent groups such as lawyers, doctors and engineers, and for the formation of political parties; and the scrapping of military and emergency courts. They announced the formation of a council to call and call off mass protests.<ref name="reuterscomm1">[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/12/us-egypt-protesters-idUSTRE71B17Q20110212 Egypt protest leaders vow to protect revolution]. Reuters. 12 February 2011. Retrieved 13 February 2011</ref><ref name="darnetcom1">[http://distributedresearch.net/blog/2011/02/13/army-protesters-egypt-democracy-communique-no-1-demands Egypt: Protesters Communique No 1 Demands to The Army]. Andy Roberts DARnet. 12 February 2011. Retrieved 13 February 2011.</ref> The hours of [[curfew]] were reduced to between [[midnight]] and 6:00 Cairo local time.<ref name="aljazeera5">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/11/live-blog-feb-12-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 12 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
A group of activists issued what they called the "People's CommuniquÃ© No 1", imitating the titles of communiquÃ©s from the Army. It demanded the dissolution of the cabinet Mubarak had appointed on 29 January; the suspension of the parliament elected in late 2010 in a poll widely suspected of rigging; the creation of a transitional five-member presidential council made up of four civilians and one military person; the formation of a transitional government to prepare for an election to take place within nine months, and of a body to draft a new democratic constitution; freedom for the media and syndicates, which represent groups such as lawyers, doctors and engineers, and for the formation of political parties; and the scrapping of military and emergency courts. They announced the formation of a council to call and call off mass protests.<ref name="reuterscomm1">[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/12/us-egypt-protesters-idUSTRE71B17Q20110212 Egypt protest leaders vow to protect revolution]. Reuters. 12 February 2011. Retrieved 13 February 2011</ref><ref name="darnetcom1">[http://distributedresearch.net/blog/2011/02/13/army-protesters-egypt-democracy-communique-no-1-demands Egypt: Protesters Communique No 1 Demands to The Army]. Andy Roberts DARnet. 12 February 2011. Retrieved 13 February 2011.</ref> The hours of [[curfew]] were reduced to between [[midnight]] and 6:00 Cairo local time.<ref name="aljazeera5">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/11/live-blog-feb-12-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 12 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
Line 16: Line 16:
In a gesture of new beginning, thousands of people began cleaning up Cairo's central Tahrir Square, which had been trashed by 18 days of rallies by hundreds of thousands of protesters and sporadic street battles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LBHFH00.html |title=Protesters press for voice in Egyptian democracy' |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
In a gesture of new beginning, thousands of people began cleaning up Cairo's central Tahrir Square, which had been trashed by 18 days of rallies by hundreds of thousands of protesters and sporadic street battles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LBHFH00.html |title=Protesters press for voice in Egyptian democracy' |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
â
=== 13 February ===
  â
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
 
[[File:People celebrating the fall of Mubarak.ogg|thumb|People celebrating on the streets of Cairo]]
[[File:People celebrating the fall of Mubarak.ogg|thumb|People celebrating on the streets of Cairo]]
The army stated that the Constitution was suspended.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egynews.net/wps/portal/news?params=115636 |title=Ø§ÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­Ø©: ØªØ¹Ø·ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙ Ø¨Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± ÙØ­Ù ÙØ¬ÙØ³Ù Ø§ÙØ´Ø¹Ø¨ ÙØ§ÙØ´ÙØ±Ù}}</ref><ref name="Leyne1">{{cite web|author=Jon Leyne |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12443678 |title=BBC News - Egyptian military dissolves parliament |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref><ref name="Deeb1">{{cite web|author=Sarah el Deeb|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LBUL700.html |title=Egypt's military rulers dissolve parliament |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> Parliament was dissolved and the military announced it would stay in power six months until [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|presidential]] and [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2011|parliamentary elections]] could be held.<ref name=Leyne1/> The High Council of Egyptian Armed Forces had selected its chief to represent the council. The caretaker Cabinet appointed by Mubarak will remain until a new Cabinet is formed after elections.<ref name=Deeb1/>
The army stated that the Constitution was suspended.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egynews.net/wps/portal/news?params=115636 |title=Ø§ÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­Ø©: ØªØ¹Ø·ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙ Ø¨Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± ÙØ­Ù ÙØ¬ÙØ³Ù Ø§ÙØ´Ø¹Ø¨ ÙØ§ÙØ´ÙØ±Ù}}</ref><ref name="Leyne1">{{cite web|author=Jon Leyne |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12443678 |title=BBC News - Egyptian military dissolves parliament |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref><ref name="Deeb1">{{cite web|author=Sarah el Deeb|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LBUL700.html |title=Egypt's military rulers dissolve parliament |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> Parliament was dissolved and the military announced it would stay in power six months until [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|presidential]] and [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2011|parliamentary elections]] could be held.<ref name=Leyne1/> The High Council of Egyptian Armed Forces had selected its chief to represent the council. The caretaker Cabinet appointed by Mubarak will remain until a new Cabinet is formed after elections.<ref name=Deeb1/>
Line 25: Line 23:
It was reported that secretary-general of the [[Arab League]] [[Amr Moussa]] was to stand down and run in the upcoming elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/02/11/feel_the_moussa_mentum |title=Feel the Moussa-mentum? | FP Passport |publisher=Blog.foreignpolicy.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
It was reported that secretary-general of the [[Arab League]] [[Amr Moussa]] was to stand down and run in the upcoming elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/02/11/feel_the_moussa_mentum |title=Feel the Moussa-mentum? | FP Passport |publisher=Blog.foreignpolicy.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
â
=== 14 February ===
  â
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
 
Eight representatives from the demonstrators, including [[Wael Ghonim]] and [[Amr Salama]], met with spokespersons of the military and reported that there would be a [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|referendum on changes to the constitution]] within two months.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – 9 hours ago |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gyvIy92hyHZzDwY3N_T-NwAdrdeQ?docId=CNG.64b40623ef755670eb1e7e108c8d3448.801 |title=AFP: Egypt cyber activists say they met military rulers |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref>
Eight representatives from the demonstrators, including [[Wael Ghonim]] and [[Amr Salama]], met with spokespersons of the military and reported that there would be a [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|referendum on changes to the constitution]] within two months.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – 9 hours ago |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gyvIy92hyHZzDwY3N_T-NwAdrdeQ?docId=CNG.64b40623ef755670eb1e7e108c8d3448.801 |title=AFP: Egypt cyber activists say they met military rulers |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref>
Military rulers called for an end to strikes and protests. Thousands of state employees, including police, transit workers and ambulance drivers, protested for better pay. In a statement from the ruling military council there appeared to be a final warning to labor unions before the armed forces intervenes and imposes an outright ban on gatherings and strikes. In addition, the army cleared out most of the remaining demonstrators from Cairo's Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110214/D9LCKQL01.html |title=Egyptian labor unrest grows after uprising |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
Military rulers called for an end to strikes and protests. Thousands of state employees, including police, transit workers and ambulance drivers, protested for better pay. In a statement from the ruling military council there appeared to be a final warning to labor unions before the armed forces intervenes and imposes an outright ban on gatherings and strikes. In addition, the army cleared out most of the remaining demonstrators from Cairo's Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110214/D9LCKQL01.html |title=Egyptian labor unrest grows after uprising |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
â
=== 15 February ===
  â
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
 
[[Tarek El-Bishry]], a retired judge known for his pro-opposition views and for his support for a strong independent judiciary, was tasked with setting up the [[Egyptian constitutional review committee of 2011|committee to reform the constitution]].<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121563130198336.html |title=Ex-judge to head Egypt reform panel - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> The changes would be formally announced within ten days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12466893 |title=BBC News - Egypt crisis: Army sets constitution reform deadline |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
[[Tarek El-Bishry]], a retired judge known for his pro-opposition views and for his support for a strong independent judiciary, was tasked with setting up the [[Egyptian constitutional review committee of 2011|committee to reform the constitution]].<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121563130198336.html |title=Ex-judge to head Egypt reform panel - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> The changes would be formally announced within ten days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12466893 |title=BBC News - Egypt crisis: Army sets constitution reform deadline |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
Adly Fayed, the director of public security at the interior ministry, and Ismail El Shaer, Cairo's security chief, have been fired over their decision to open fire on the demonstrators.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Adly Fayed, the director of public security at the interior ministry, and Ismail El Shaer, Cairo's security chief, have been fired over their decision to open fire on the demonstrators.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Line 85: Line 79:
== March ==
== March ==
â   â
=== 1 March ===
  â
{{Empty section|date=March 2011}}
  â   â
=== 2 March ===
  â
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
 
The [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] has been tentatively scheduled for 19 March 2011, but the date is yet to be officially confirmed.<ref>http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d67e07da-4420-11e0-931d-00144feab49a.html#axzz1FTmeSur8</ref>
The [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] has been tentatively scheduled for 19 March 2011, but the date is yet to be officially confirmed.<ref>http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d67e07da-4420-11e0-931d-00144feab49a.html#axzz1FTmeSur8</ref>
â
=== 3 March ===
  â
{{incomplete|section|date=March 2011}}
 
A day before large protests against him were planned, [[Ahmed Shafik]] stepped down as PM and was replaced by [[Essam Sharaf]].<ref>http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypts-prime-minsiter-quits-new-govt-soon-army-2011-03-03T093300Z</ref>
A day before large protests against him were planned, [[Ahmed Shafik]] stepped down as PM and was replaced by [[Essam Sharaf]].<ref>http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypts-prime-minsiter-quits-new-govt-soon-army-2011-03-03T093300Z</ref>
â   â
=== 4 March ===
 
Sharaf returned to [[Tahrir Square]] (which he had also visited during the revolution) to address the Friday mass rally.<ref>http://www.rferl.org/content/egypt_sharaf/2328017.html</ref>
Sharaf returned to [[Tahrir Square]] (which he had also visited during the revolution) to address the Friday mass rally.<ref>http://www.rferl.org/content/egypt_sharaf/2328017.html</ref>
â   â
=== 5 March===
 
Following rumours that officials were destroying evidence, 200 protesters stormed the headquarters of the secret police in Cairo. The closing of the agency has been the key demand of the protesters which has not yet been heeded; it is accused of human rights abuses including torture. The protesters stated they stormed the building to secure evidence, as they feared that it might be destroyed.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12657464</ref>
Following rumours that officials were destroying evidence, 200 protesters stormed the headquarters of the secret police in Cairo. The closing of the agency has been the key demand of the protesters which has not yet been heeded; it is accused of human rights abuses including torture. The protesters stated they stormed the building to secure evidence, as they feared that it might be destroyed.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12657464</ref>
â
=== 6 March ===
 
Two new ministers were named: General [[Mansour El Essawi]] became interior minister and former judge [[Nabil El Arabi]] was appointed foreign minister.<ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011365436227288.html</ref>
Two new ministers were named: General [[Mansour El Essawi]] became interior minister and former judge [[Nabil El Arabi]] was appointed foreign minister.<ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011365436227288.html</ref>
